name: Römerberg
description: picturesque town square; the historical focal point of the city, a cobbled plaza lined with original and reconstructed half-timber medieval buildings including the Römer (Frankfurt’s town hall) and the Alte Nikolaikirche (St Nicholas’ Church), which you can visit if there are no meetings or events on.

name: Iron Footbridge
description: Fantastic views and thousands of love locks.

name: Alter Flugplatz Frankfurt am Main
description: Revitalization efforts converted a former U.S. military heliport into a sprawling urban park.

name: Verkehrsmuseum Frankfurt am Main
description: This museum explores the history of the city's public transportation. Its collection includes the world's oldest preserved electric trolley car.

name: Flemings Selection Hotel Frankfurt-City - paternoster
description: The lift is currently working, although passengers can only disembark on the top floor when the bar is open (starting at 5:30 pm) . Otherwise you get out on the 5th floor and walk up one flight of stairs.

name: IG Farben Building
description: From Nazi chemicals to the CIA, this architectural marvel has played a fascinating role in German history.

name: Dialog Museum
description: This unique exhibit "Dialogue in the Dark" reverses roles as the visionless become guides and the sighted become ‘blind.’

name: Pinkelbaum
description: After years of being casually peed on by humans, this tree is peeing back.

name: Bockenheimer Warte
description: The entrance to this Frankfurt subway station looks like an old tram car crashed into the concrete sidewalk.

name: Bauernmarkt Konstablerwache
description: thursday and saturday there's always a weekly regional farmers market on top of the train station "Konstablerwache"(it's in the city centre) they offer some very good sausages and there's also one sausage stand that sells apple juice as well, it's so good. There's also a tiny butchers cart hidden in the back he sells a very good pulled beef sandwich for very cheap and there's also a foodtruck which sells dairy products (ice cream, milkshakes etc.

name: Alte Oper
description:
Frankfurt's most beautiful concert hall hosts pop and jazz concerts, musicals and a festival that makes classical music accessible to everyone. Everything but operas.
If she were a person, you could call her the "grande dame" of Frankfurt's cultural institutions: the Alte Oper. And as befits a star, it can look back on a lot of glamour and drama. The construction of the 34-metre-high Wilhelminian-style building was made possible by 67 wealthy Frankfurt citizens, and when it opened in 1880, even Kaiser Wilhelm I was amazed. It soon blossomed into one of the most important opera houses in the country.
After its destruction in the Second World War, it was to take more than 35 years before it was reopened in 1981 – and once again brought famous conductors, soloists, ensembles and orchestras to the stage – only no more operas, which can be found in the "new" opera house. Instead, in addition to world-class classical stars, pop, jazz and chanson artists also perform at around 460 events each year, as well as musicals and show productions. Each new season begins with the Fratopia Festival, which offers low-threshold classical music in the form of short concerts – without admission and without registration.
